content.description:
Pitch 1: Follow an obvious prow full of cracks and an easy roof about 3/4 of the way up. Pitch ends on a decent ledge. Gear belay. Fixed nut in place. 

Pitch 2: Follow prow and cracks to a tight notch at the top of the route. Gear belay with a fixed nut. 

Descent: Rappel on fixed nuts. The first rappel will reach the top of the first pitch. One can rappel off the fixed nut at the top of the first pitch but they will come up at least a few meters short. One can rappel to the climber's right to lower angle rock. There is a fixed nut in the area (might be hard to find) to make a short rappel to the ground. The terrain is very easy either way and down climbing would be easy. Another option is to rappel the single-bolted anchors from Shitty Sugarpants and there is always the option of walking off. The mountain goats have left a decent trail along the top of the wall. 



Prominent prow with an obvious south-facing wide crack-The climb starts to the left. 

All Gear.

Follow solid cracks to about mid-way up the wall and trend left. Near the top ascent and easy arete to exit to the climbers left of the prominent roofs at the top of the wall. 



Climb the left side of the prominent prow that leads to the upper left portion of the roofs atop the wall. 

All gear-no bolts

P1: Climb easy terrain on a low angle arete features to a single bolt belay. 

P2: Climb towards the roof feature with cracks. Clip the bolt and climb straight up to the roof cracks or traverse right with better gear to the corner. Once at the base of the low angle corner, traverse left to gain a wide crack- climb until the crack ends at single bolt belay. 

P3: Climb in the deep corner to the steeper corner with a finger crack. Once atop, traverse left to clip a bolt and climb crack. Once the crack trends left, climb the slab, clip bolt, and gain the last belay. 



Look for the notable roof on the wall with nice looking cracks-This will be on the second pitch which will start about 30' below the roof. 

Mostly trad-3 protection bolts on the whole climb. Belays are single bolt except atop the last pitch- there are two bolts here but be wary of the bolt on the right. We ran out of drill power and could not get a deep enough hole that prevented up from being able to tighten the bolt properly.
High quality alpine rock-some of the best in the Northwest. The best time to climb is September and October. Late August might be ok.
